millsfield:images_texts:
Thing Clippervise
IN YOUR DOUBLE
DECKED
'STRATO"
CLIPPER
PAA

Glad
To Have You With Us
We're truly pleased that you chose to make this trip via Pan
American World Airways.
and end I do our utmost to mare
you feel at home.
As a maller of fact, the main reason for producing this little
booklet was to acquaint you more fully with our operation,
our aircraft and our personnel.
Since this is a small volume, there's a good chance you won't
find all the answers to your questions. In which case, just
call on one of the cabin allendants. Most of the time, they'll
know the answers. If not, they'll be glad to find out.
ASSET PAS ARENA
Glibber. Trademark Rec. U.S. Pareas Ofce
Just Like Home... With a Difference
Perhaps we're taking a lot for granted. It's just possible that
your home does have an air conditioning system which
changes the air completely every ninety seconds. And
maybe it boasts a lounge with view clear to the horizon.
Your personal palace may even contain luxurious sleeping
accommodations for more than a dozen people. BUT -
we'll wager it doesn't whisk you across the world, 25,000
feet up, at over 300 miles per hour. (If it does, may we pay
you a visit? That's a trick we'd like to see.)
Seriously, the Double-Decked "Strato" Clippers, the type
in which you are now relaxing, were carefully designed
to offer you all the comforts of your own living room. With,
of course, a few delightful differences, to which we'd like
to point, with pardonable pride, in the next few pages
But first, may we introduce some nice people?

YOUR CLIPPER LOG
If you would like to take home a day-by-day record of
this trip by Clipper, just fill in the blank lines below.
Your stewardess will be glad to turnish missing
and numbers.

how to
CIFAR U.S.CUSTOMS
the EASIEST way
HELPFuL hints for
RETURNING AMERICANS AND VISITORS TO THE
UNITED STATES FROM FOREIGN LANDS TRAVELING
VIA PAN AMERICAN WORLD AIRWAYS

meet the U. S. CUSTOMS:
the rules are simple
knowing them can ease you
through inspections , fast!
Whether you're homeward bound . . . or making
your first visit to the United States . . . there's
no need to fear delay or inconvenience at the
customs. There are rules, of course - but all of
them are sensible - and set up simply to protect
the United States, its citizens, and its visitors.
But since these rules are enforced without ex-
ception, we thought you'd like to look over the
ones that affect you ... plus some hints to speed
you through customs.
For instance, it's faster to pack dutiable items
together. It's easier to list each one as you pack
it. It's safer to check your final list with your sales
slips see that everything is listed correctly.
Then you have only to copy this list on the U.S.
Customs declaration form - which you will be
given by your purser aboard the Clipper - with
ease and speed.
Of course, traveling by Pan American "Clipper"
you're at your destination before there's any need
to disturb that final packing - and you avoid the
havoc which would result from having to live out
of your luggage en route.
When you land at the U.S. Port of Entry, there
are several questions you'll have to answer: How
long you ve been gone trom the country
what you acquired on your trip.
. what you
have to declare.
And your answers are important! An uninten-
tional error or omission can cause you consider
able inconvenience . : . and misrepresentation
can result in loss of your free-entry privileges or
in some cases, confiscation of your belongings.
We think you'll find these suggestions an aid to
a more pleasant trip. And you can count on their
accuracy . . . the United States
Government
supplied us with its latest regulations.
what every returni
U. S. resident
should know
If you're a U.S. resident, your Uncle Sam gives
you certain privileges as a returing tourist. For
instance, you don't have to pay duty on many
articles you buy abroad. But that doesn't mean
you can just cram your suitcases and cruise
through the customs. There are declarations to
make. There are time limits to watch. And there's
the matter of what an article is worth. You'll find
most of these rules explained below.
WELL I DECLARE.
You'll have to declare in writing anything ac-
quired abroad which (1) you are bringing in for
someone else at that person's request; (2) you
intend to sell or use in business; (3) you
bringing home for personal or household use or
as a souvenir or curio; (4) all alterations and any
repairs to articles taken abroad, other than nec-
essary repairs to restore an article to the condition
it was in when taken abroad.
But what about gifts or other articles you've
sent on home ahead of your arrival . .. or ar-
ranged to have shipped later? To include such
articles under exemptions, you must declare them
with the rest.
